Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Computer Architectures and Algorithms for Adaptive Human Computer Interfaces

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ease of use of a human computer interface depends critically on the latency of the system and its ability to adapt to the environment. Differences in lighting, visual appearance and user behavior can significantly alter the input data. Furthermore, the reaction time must be less than 100 milliseconds to appear instantaneous to the user. Achieving high accuracy demands a system that adapts to these changing characteristics while processing a significant amount of data in a short amount of time.

We propose a computer architecture for adaptive real-time signal processing systems that combines a general purpose processor with custom hardware. The custom hardware performs the low-level, high-throughput signal processing on the raw signals and feeds them to the processor which performs the high level signal processing and decision making. The processor also executes machine learning algorithms that change the parameters of the low-level processing to adapt them to the current statistical properties of the data.

This project will develop a human-computer interface based on audio and video sensors that allows a user to interact with the computer through gestures and voice alone. This requires research advances in computer architecture, embedded systems, signal processing, machine learning and human-computer interaction. The major research challenge is in the integration of knowledge from the different areas to create a functional system. This system will serve as a prototype for novel human computer interactions and will be a foundation for future collaboration between the different fields.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research developed over the course of this grant focused on techniques in human-computer interaction. The motivating application was apparatus free handwriting recognition using only a video camera and a monitor. Users engage the system by drawing characters in free space using their hand. The hand is tracked using a hardware accelerated computing system. The tracking location is provided to the handwriting recognition algorithm using a hardware accelerated system.  The handwriting recognition algorithm uses the input to adapt to the user's style of writing. The research was divided into two parts: adaptive handwriting recognition and hardware accelerated tracking.

 

Adaptive Handwriting Recognition: Handwriting recognition is an accessible and natural data-entry method. In many situations it is preferable to the keyboard, e.g., in smart phones and no-touch interfaces. However, as handwriting is highly variable, it is hard to design handwriting recognizers that are effective for all writers.  One solution is to use machine learning to adapt the recognizers. However, a complicating factor is that the user is likely to adapt to the computer at the same time that the computer is adapting to the user.

 

We developed a theoretical framework for quantifying the rate at which information flows through a handwriting recognition system. We developed handwriting recognition software, deployed it as an iPhone App called uRight and collected data using a game-based experiment. Using this experiment, we quantify the effect of user and computer adaptivity on the data transfer rate. We also provide a method for quantifying and visualizing the transmission of information as a function of time within the time that a single character is written.

 

Hardware Accelerated Tracking: Input control algorithms for consumer devices, computers, or interactive virtual/augmented reality environments are only as good as the accuracy of the tracking data describing such input. High fidelity object tracking is therefore a requirement for most gesture recognition systems. Tracking effectively translates high bandwidth sensor information to a low bandwidth set of data points for higher level algorithms.

 

Robust optical tracking in noisy environments is a computationally challenging task. General purpose computers are ill suited for this task because of their sequential processing nature. We developed a system that uses the computational flexibility of a general purpose computer and the dedicated processing power of a field programmable gate array (FPGA) to achieve high performance tracking. The algorithm uses online boosting to adapt the appearance model to changes in real time. The use of the FPGA allows us to track multiple points at high frame rates with low latency.
